paraphrased: You arrive with utmost care during your scheduled time.

paraphrased: It's midnight now, Francisco. Go to bed.

dialogue: For this relief much thanks: 'tis bitter cold,
paraphrased: I'm grateful for the warmth: it's freezing out here!

dialogue: And I am sick at heart.
paraphrased: I'm feeling deeply disappointed.

dialogue: Have you had quiet guard?
paraphrased: Have you kept a peaceful watch recently?

dialogue: Not a mouse stirring.
paraphrased: Not a single mouse moving.

dialogue: Well, good night.
paraphrased: Goodnight! See you tomorrow.

paraphrased: If you encounter Horatio and Marcellus

paraphrased: If this apparition appears again:

dialogue: That are so fortified against our story
paraphrased: Those are incredibly well-defended against our tale.

paraphrased: With that fair and warrior-like figure

 Frankly speaking, I wouldn't automatically accept it as true. (less informal)

paraphrased: When ambitious Norway was in conflict;

dialogue: 'Tis strange.

paraphrased: And a marketplace for weapons from other countries;

paraphrased: Treats Sunday as just another day of the week.

dialogue: The head is not more native to the heart,

paraphrased: From where I voluntarily traveled to Denmark.

dialogue: To show my duty in your coronation,
paraphrased: To demonstrate my loyalty during your coronation,

dialogue: Yet now, I must confess, that duty done,
paraphrased: Now, I have to admit, after completing that task,

paraphrased: My mind and heart are drawn back to France once more.

paraphrased: And spend your best graces as you wish!

paraphrased: However, now, my cousin Hamlet and my child,

paraphrased: And may your gaze be as friendly towards Denmark.

Both interpretations are grammatically correct and convey similar meanings. Shakespeare's original line is a beautiful quote from Hamlet, Act 3, Scene 1: "To be, or not to be: that is the question: / Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer / The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, / Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, / And by opposing end them? To dieto sleep; / No more; and by a sleep to say we end / The heartache and the thousand natural shocks / That flesh is heir to'tis a consummation / Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep; / To sleep, perchance to dreamay, there's the rub: / For in that sleep of death what dreams may come / When we have shuffled off this mortal coil, / Must give us pause: there's the respect / That makes calamity of so long life."

dialogue: Enter a King and a Queen very lovingly; the Queen  embracing him, and he her. She kneels, and makes  show of protestation unto him. He takes her up,  and declines his head upon her neck: lays him down  upon a bank of flowers: she, seeing him asleep,  leaves him. Anon comes in a fellow, takes off his  crown, kisses it, and pours poison in the King's  ears, and exit. The Queen returns; finds the King  dead, and makes passionate action. The Poisoner,  with some two or three Mutes, comes in again,  seeming to lament with her. The dead body is  carried away. The Poisoner wooes the Queen with  gifts: she seems loath and unwilling awhile, but in the end accepts his love
paraphrased: A king and queen enter together, displaying affection; the queen hugging him, and he returning the gesture. She pretends to protest, and he lifts her up, lowering his head on her shoulder before laying down among a bed of flowers. Alone, another person enters, removes the king's crown, kisses it, then pours poison in the king's ears and leaves. The queen returns to find the king dead, expressing distress. Later, the same individual comes back with gifts, trying to win the queen's affection. At first, she resists, but eventually accepts his advances.

paraphrased: Leave, Polonius.

dialogue: O, my offence is rank it smells to heaven;
paraphrased: Oh, my crime is so foul, it stinks even in heaven.

dialogue: It hath the primal eldest curse upon't,
paraphrased: It carries the original ancient curse.

dialogue: A brother's murder. Pray can I not,
paraphrased: The murder of a sibling. Can I not pray?

dialogue: Though inclination be as sharp as will:
paraphrased: Despite strong desire, willpower may still rule.

dialogue: My stronger guilt defeats my strong intent;
paraphrased: My strong guilt overpowers my strong intention.

dialogue: And, like a man to double business bound,
paraphrased:
And, like a person juggling multiple tasks,

or

And, just as someone with two jobs,

or

And, much like a multitasker,

or

And, similar to one keeping busy on two fronts,

or

And, in the manner of a double-duty individual,

These variations maintain the original's poetic nuance while updating the language.

dialogue: I stand in pause where I shall first begin,
paraphrased: I'm about to start at this point; let me gather myself here for a moment.

dialogue: And both neglect. What if this cursed hand
paraphrased: And they both disregard it. What if this accursed hand...

dialogue: Were thicker than itself with brother's blood,
paraphrased: It's thicker than its own self due to brotherly ties.

dialogue: Is there not rain enough in the sweet heavens
paraphrased: Isn't it raining enough up there?

dialogue: To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy
paraphrased: To make it as clean as freshly fallen snow, what is the purpose of kindness?

dialogue: But to confront the visage of offence?
paraphrased: To face the image of something that's offensive?

dialogue: And what's in prayer but this two-fold force,
paraphrased: And what is prayer other than this dual power?

dialogue: To be forestalled ere we come to fall,
paraphrased: To prevent something from happening before it causes us to fail

dialogue: Or pardon'd being down? Then I'll look up;
paraphrased: Or if forgiven, am I falling down? Then I'll stand up.

dialogue: My fault is past. But, O, what form of prayer
paraphrased: My mistake is behind me. Yet, what kind of plea... (Note: "O" is used for emphasis and is equivalent to "Oh" in modern English)

dialogue: Can serve my turn? 'Forgive me my foul murder'?
paraphrased: Can I take my turn now? 'May I be forgiven for this heinous act of killing?'

dialogue: That cannot be; since I am still possess'd
paraphrased: That can't be right; I'm still in possession of it.

dialogue: Of those effects for which I did the murder,
paraphrased:
For the consequences of the murder I committed,

Or more colloquially:

The reasons behind my murder were...

Or even shorter:

Why I murdered was due to...

dialogue: My crown, mine own ambition and my queen.
paraphrased: My crown, my personal aspiration and my sovereign.

dialogue: May one be pardon'd and retain the offence?
paraphrased: Can someone be forgiven while still keeping the offense?

dialogue: In the corrupted currents of this world
paraphrased: Navigating the dishonest streams of today's society

dialogue: Offence's gilded hand may shove by justice,
paraphrased: Injustice can sometimes overpower justice.

dialogue: And oft 'tis seen the wicked prize itself
paraphrased: And often, the wicked reap their own rewards. (or) The wicked sometimes end up benefiting themselves.

dialogue: Buys out the law: but 'tis not so above;
paraphrased:
Buying out the law may work here, but it doesn't fly in higher circles; or

Bribing the law might seem effective down below, but it won't cut it up there.

dialogue: There is no shuffling, there the action lies
paraphrased: There's no hesitation; the action unfolds there.

dialogue: In his true nature; and we ourselves compell'd,
paraphrased: In his genuine character; and feeling compelled ourselves,

dialogue: Even to the teeth and forehead of our faults,
paraphrased: Even to the roots and brows of our imperfections,

dialogue: To give in evidence. What then? what rests?
paraphrased: To present as proof, what remains?

dialogue: Try what repentance can: what can it not?
paraphrased:
Attempt what repentance offers: what does it not? (Simplified)

   Give repentance a shot: what can't it do? (Informal)

dialogue: Yet what can it when one can not repent?
paraphrased: Yet, what change is there when one cannot apologize or make amends?

dialogue: O wretched state! O bosom black as death!
paraphrased: Oh, miserable condition! Oh, heart as dark as death itself!

dialogue: O limed soul, that, struggling to be free,
paraphrased: Struggling soul trying to break free

dialogue: Art more engaged! Help, angels! Make assay!
paraphrased: Art more active! Help, helpers! Let's try!

dialogue: Bow, stubborn knees; and, heart with strings of steel,
paraphrased: Kneel down reluctantly, and harden your heart with steel-like cords.

dialogue: Be soft as sinews of the newborn babe!
paraphrased: Be tender and gentle, like a newborn baby's softness!

dialogue: All may be well.
paraphrased: Everything could be fine.

dialogue: Retires and kneels
paraphrased: Stops working and gets down on one knee

dialogue: Enter HAMLET
paraphrased: Open Hamlet

dialogue: Now might I do it pat, now he is praying;
paraphrased: Now seems like a good time for me to act, now he's praying.

dialogue: And now I'll do't. And so he goes to heaven;
paraphrased: Now, I will take care of it. That's where he heads off (figuratively).

dialogue: And so am I revenged. That would be scann'd:
paraphrased: And thus, my revenge is complete. (Modern English)

dialogue: A villain kills my father; and for that,
paraphrased: A wicked person murders my dad, and I seek revenge because of it.

dialogue: I, his sole son, do this same villain send
paraphrased: I, his only child, carry out this wicked person's task.

dialogue: To heaven.
paraphrased: To the skies.

dialogue: O, this is hire and salary, not revenge.
paraphrased: Oh, this is about pay and wages, not retaliation.

dialogue: He took my father grossly, full of bread;
paraphrased: He ate my father's food excessively.

dialogue: With all his crimes broad blown, as flush as May;
paraphrased: With all his crimes clearly exposed, as evident as a sunny day in May.

dialogue: And how his audit stands who knows save heaven?
paraphrased: And only heaven knows how his audit stands.

dialogue: But in our circumstance and course of thought,
paraphrased: However, given our current situation and way of thinking,

dialogue: 'Tis heavy with him: and am I then revenged,
paraphrased: It's a burden for him; if I do this, am I then avenging myself?

dialogue: To take him in the purging of his soul,
paraphrased: To help purify his spirit, I'll assist him.

dialogue: When he is fit and season'd for his passage?
paraphrased: When is he ready for his journey?

dialogue: No!
paraphrased: "No way!"

dialogue: Up, sword; and know thou a more horrid hent:
paraphrased: Lift up your sword, and understand that there is a far more terrible fate ahead.

dialogue: When he is drunk asleep, or in his rage,
paraphrased: When he's passed out from drinking, enraged, or angry.

dialogue: Or in the incestuous pleasure of his bed;
paraphrased: Or indulging in intimacy within his family's quarters;

dialogue: At gaming, swearing, or about some act
paraphrased: In gaming, using profanity, or discussing certain actions

dialogue: That has no relish of salvation in't;
paraphrased: It doesn't have a hint of salvation about it.

dialogue: Then trip him, that his heels may kick at heaven,
paraphrased: Then, kick him hard enough so he flails and kicks wildly, reaching towards the sky.

dialogue: And that his soul may be as damn'd and black
paraphrased: And that his soul may be as condemned and dark

dialogue: As hell, whereto it goes. My mother stays:
paraphrased: To wherever it's headed. My mom will remain.

dialogue: This physic but prolongs thy sickly days.
paraphrased: This physics is only extending your unhealthy period.

dialogue: Exit
paraphrased: Leave / Depart

dialogue: [Rising]  My words fly up, my thoughts remain below:
paraphrased: My words soar aloft, my thoughts stay grounded.

dialogue: Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
paraphrased: Thoughts, not just words, ascend to heaven.

dialogue: Exit
paraphrased: Leave / Depart

dialogue: Enter QUEEN GERTRUDE and POLONIUS
paraphrased:
Enter Queen Gertrude and Polonius

In this context, "enter" refers to the characters making their appearance on stage.

dialogue: He will come straight. Look you lay home to him:
paraphrased: He's coming directly. Make sure you stay home for him.

dialogue: Tell him his pranks have been too broad to bear with,
paraphrased: Ask him to stop with the jokes, they've become a bit too much to handle.

paraphrased: And it shielded and defended you from harm.

paraphrased: A lot of heat is here, and I'll hide myself too. (Modernized)

paraphrased: Please accompany him.

paraphrased: Mom, mom, mom!

paraphrased: I can assure you.

dialogue: Fear me not: withdraw, I hear him coming.
paraphrased: Don't be afraid; step back, I can hear him approaching.

paraphrased: Polonius conceals himself behind the curtains (or a piece of furniture covered with curtains).

paraphrased: Walk into Hamlet's presence

dialogue: Now, mother, what's the matter?
paraphrased: Hey mom, what's up?

paraphrased: Hamlet, you've greatly upset your father.

paraphrased: Mom, you've really upset Dad.

paraphrased:
What's up, Hamlet? (Informal)

or

paraphrased: Haven't we crossed paths recently?

dialogue: No, by the rood, not so:

paraphrased: You're the queen, you're married to your husband's brother's spouse.

dialogue: And--would it were not so!--you are my mother.
paraphrased: And, if only it weren't true, you are my mom.

paraphrased: No, only those who can talk will get them (meaning the tasks).

paraphrased: You won't go until I get you a drink.

paraphrased: Oh, I've been killed!

dialogue: Falls and dies
paraphrased: Falls and perishes/meets its end

paraphrased: Oh, what have I done?

paraphrased: Is that the monarch?

paraphrased: Oh, what a hasty and violent act this is!

paraphrased: Oh my, what a terrible act! Almost as horrific, dear mother.

paraphrased: As killing a king and marrying his brother. (This line is from Shakespeare's "Hamlet," where it is spoken by King Claudius about his actions.)

paraphrased: As deadly as killing a king!

Stop hand-wringing, find a spot to sit: Peace.

paraphrased: And let me touch your emotions; I will achieve this.

paraphrased: If it's made of material that can be penetrated,

paraphrased: That it serves as evidence and protection for reasoning.

paraphrased: Is there such a loud racket disturbing you?

paraphrased: Such an action

paraphrased: And causes a blister there, takes wedding vows

paraphrased: As unreliable as a dice-thrower's vow: Oh, what a dishonest act!

paraphrased: As it extracts from a contracted form

paraphrased: A burst of beautiful language: Heaven radiates a soft glow:

paraphrased: Indeed, this solid structure and dense matter,

paraphrased: With a mournful expression, facing the inevitable

paraphrased: Finds the action distressing, mentally speaking.

paraphrased: Oh no, what did I do?

paraphrased: Hyperion's wavy hair; the very image of Jupiter himself;

paraphrased: An intense gaze, imposing and authoritative, reminiscent of Mars.

paraphrased: Shone on a hill that kissed the sky;

paraphrased: A blend and a shape, truly

paraphrased: Where every deity appeared to leave their mark

paraphrased: Destroying your innocent sibling. Can you see it?

paraphrased: Can you please go graze here on this beautiful mountain?

dialogue: And batten on this moor? Ha! have you eyes?
paraphrased: And camp out on that moor? Ha! Don't you have any sight?

paraphrased: At your age, you can't really say it's love.

paraphrased: The prime of life is subdued, it's modest

dialogue: Would step from this to this? Sense, sure, you have,
paraphrased: Are you planning on moving from here to there? I assume you're aware of that, right?

dialogue: Else could you not have motion; but sure, that sense
paraphrased: Else, you wouldn't be able to move; however, having senses is a given.

paraphrased: Is having a stroke; insanity wouldn't make a mistake. (Modernized)

paraphrased: However, it left some room for selection or decision-making.

paraphrased: To make such a distinction. What on earth was it?

paraphrased: Have they swindled you in a card game, blind man's bluff?

paraphrased: Eyes devoid of emotions, feelings bereft of vision

paraphrased: Ears lacking hands and sight, but still able to smell.

paraphrased: Or buy a part that's unwell, representing reality

paraphrased: Oh, disgrace! Where's your embarrassment? You rebellious, fiery underworld.

paraphrased: If you can stir unrest within someone's body (modern idiom: If you can make someone feel restless)

paraphrased: To young people, let virtues be like wax (easily shaped and adaptable).

paraphrased: And burn in her own flames: feel no embarrassment

dialogue: When the compulsive ardour gives the charge,

paraphrased: Because frost itself actively seems to scorch

paraphrased: And rationalizations prevail.

paraphrased: Oh Hamlet, don't say another word.

paraphrased: And there, I notice those dark, speckled marks.

paraphrased: They won't abandon their territory.

paraphrased: No, but to exist

paraphrased: Swimming in corruption, disguising it with sweetness and expressing affection

paraphrased: Over the filthy street,-- (Modern: Over the dirty street,--)

paraphrased: Please don't talk to me anymore.

paraphrased: These words pierce my ears, similar to daggers.

paraphrased: Of your former lord; a flaw in kingship;

paraphrased: Stole the precious diadem from the shelf

paraphrased: And put it in your pocket!

dialogue: No more!
paraphrased: Enough already!

paraphrased: A ruler with a patchy, inconsistent reign.

paraphrased: Save me and shield me with your protection.

paraphrased: Heavenly guardians, what does your benevolent presence intend?

paraphrased: Oh no, he's crazy!

paraphrased: Aren't you coming to scold your late son?

paraphrased: What's the key action from your urgent order? Tell me, please!

paraphrased: Don't overlook: this visit.

paraphrased: Is merely to sharpen your nearly faded resolve.

paraphrased: But, check this out, your mom looks astonished:

paraphrased: Oh, intervene between her and her fierce spirit.

paraphrased: You're looking at emptiness, right?

paraphrased: And are you having a conversation with the invisible air?

paraphrased: Before your very eyes, your wild spirits seem to appear

paraphrased: Ecstatic joy!

paraphrased: And produces healthy, pleasant sounds. It's not insanity.

paraphrased: It won't give way to Norway or Poland.

paraphrased: The Pole won't defend it, then.

dialogue: That inward breaks, and shows no cause without
paraphrased: It conceals the reason for its inner turmoil.

dialogue: Why the man dies. I humbly thank you, sir.

dialogue: God be wi' you, sir.

paraphrased: And ignite my dormant anger! What's a human being,

dialogue: Looking before and after, gave us not

That ability and intelligent understanding (similar to a deity)

paraphrased: To gather dust in us unutilized. Now, if it matters or not.

paraphrased: A thought that's divided in four only contains a single portion of wisdom.

paraphrased: Behold this immense and powerful force.

paraphrased: For a fantasy or publicity stunt,

dialogue: That carry but half sense: her speech is nothing,

paraphrased: However, its improper usage can be problematic.

paraphrased: Unfounded assumptions in uneducated minds.

paraphrased: Here, Hamlet, use this napkin to wipe your forehead.

dialogue: The queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.
paraphrased: The queen celebrates your luck, Hamlet.

dialogue: Good madam!
paraphrased: Dear ma'am!

dialogue: Gertrude, do not drink.
paraphrased: Gertrude, don't consume alcohol.

dialogue: I will, my lord; I pray you, pardon me.
paraphrased: I will, my lord, please forgive me.

dialogue: [Aside]  It is the poison'd cup: it is too late.
paraphrased: It's the tainted drink now: it's already past time.

dialogue: I dare not drink yet, madam; by and by.
paraphrased: I'm not ready to have a drink right now, ma'am; soon enough.

dialogue: Come, let me wipe thy face.
paraphrased: Come, let me clean your face for you.

dialogue: My lord, I'll hit him now.
paraphrased: My lord, I'm going to strike him right away.

dialogue: I do not think't.
paraphrased: I don't think so.

dialogue: [Aside]  And yet 'tis almost 'gainst my conscience.
paraphrased: Almost goes against my conscious judgment.

dialogue: Come, for the third, Laertes: you but dally;
paraphrased: Come on now, Laertes, you're tardy; stop delaying.

dialogue: I pray you, pass with your best violence;
paraphrased: Please, act with utmost force; (or) Please, exert your greatest power.

dialogue: I am afeard you make a wanton of me.
paraphrased: I'm afraid you're taking advantage of me.

dialogue: Say you so? come on.
paraphrased: Say that for sure? Come on.

dialogue: They play
paraphrased: They're playing

dialogue: Nothing, neither way.
paraphrased: Nothing whatsoever.

dialogue: Have at you now!
paraphrased: Let's engage now!

dialogue: LAERTES wounds HAMLET; then in scuffling, they change rapiers, and HAMLET wounds LAERTES
paraphrased: In the ensuing struggle, Laertes wounds Hamlet, but during the commotion, they swap swords, resulting in Hamlet wounding Laertes.

dialogue: Part them; they are incensed.
paraphrased: Separate them, they are enraged.

dialogue: Nay, come, again.
paraphrased: No, please come back again.

dialogue: QUEEN GERTRUDE falls
paraphrased: Queen Gertrude collapses

dialogue: Look to the queen there, ho!
paraphrased: Check out that queen over there!

dialogue: They bleed on both sides. How is it, my lord?
paraphrased: They're bleeding from both sides. What's going on, my lord?

dialogue: How is't, Laertes?
paraphrased: How are you, Laertes?

dialogue: Why, as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric;
paraphrased: Why, just like a woodcock to its trap, Osric; (in this context, "mine" is an old-fashioned form of "my")

dialogue: I am justly kill'd with mine own treachery.
paraphrased: I was justifiably killed by my own deceit.

dialogue: How does the queen?
paraphrased: How is the queen doing?

dialogue: She swounds to see them bleed.
paraphrased: She watches intently as they wound.

dialogue: No, no, the drink, the drink,--O my dear Hamlet,--
paraphrased:
No, no, it's the drink, Hamlet, dear. (informal)
   Or:
   No, no, that's the drink, Hamlet, buddy. (even more informal)

dialogue: The drink, the drink! I am poison'd.
paraphrased: The drink, that drink has poisoned me.

dialogue: Dies
paraphrased: Dies? That's German for "dies" which means "this (one)" or "these (ones)". In a sentence, it could be "This is my book." or "These are my apples.", depending on the context.

dialogue: O villany! Ho! let the door be lock'd:
paraphrased: Oh wickedness! Let the door be locked, please.

dialogue: Treachery! Seek it out.
paraphrased: Betrayal! Find it out.

dialogue: It is here, Hamlet: Hamlet, thou art slain;
paraphrased: Here, Hamlet: You are dead, Hamlet.

dialogue: No medicine in the world can do thee good;
paraphrased: No medicine on Earth can help you now.

dialogue: In thee there is not half an hour of life;
paraphrased: You don't have more than a half-hour left to live.

dialogue: The treacherous instrument is in thy hand,
paraphrased: The treacherous tool is in your possession.

dialogue: Unbated and envenom'd: the foul practise
paraphrased: Unvaccinated and venomous: the harmful act

dialogue: Hath turn'd itself on me lo, here I lie,
paraphrased: It has turned against me, now I find myself lying here.

dialogue: Never to rise again: thy mother's poison'd:
paraphrased: Never to wake up again, she was killed by poison: (mother)

dialogue: I can no more: the king, the king's to blame.
paraphrased: I cannot do it: it's the king who is responsible.

dialogue: The point!--envenom'd too!
paraphrased:
The point -- it's been poisoned, too! (Shakespeare's Hamlet, Act III Scene IV)

The point is -- it's gotten toxic as well! (Modern English)

dialogue: Then, venom, to thy work.
paraphrased: Then, unleash your venomous act.

dialogue: Stabs KING CLAUDIUS
paraphrased: Stabs King Claudius

dialogue: Treason! treason!
paraphrased: Traitorous actions! Traitorous actions!

dialogue: O, yet defend me, friends; I am but hurt.
paraphrased: Oh, please, help me out here, guys; I'm just wounded.

dialogue: Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damned Dane,
paraphrased: Here, you incestuous, murderous, cursed Dane,

dialogue: Drink off this potion. Is thy union here?
paraphrased: Drink this potion. Are you both present?

dialogue: Follow my mother.
paraphrased: Follow my mum.

dialogue: KING CLAUDIUS dies
paraphrased: King Claudius passes away.

dialogue: He is justly served;
paraphrased: He is rightfully treated.

dialogue: It is a poison temper'd by himself.
paraphrased: It's a poison he's made harmless himself.

dialogue: Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet:
paraphrased: Grant me forgiveness, honorable Hamlet. (Modernized Shakespeare)

dialogue: Mine and my father's death come not upon thee,
paraphrased: Neither my nor my father's demise will befall you.

dialogue: Nor thine on me.
paraphrased: Not on me, too.

dialogue: Dies
paraphrased: Dies is short for "diesel," a type of fuel used for vehicles. In modern English, we would simply say: "This is diesel."

dialogue: Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee.
paraphrased: May you be liberated from it! I'll follow along.

dialogue: I am dead, Horatio. Wretched queen, adieu!
paraphrased: I'm dead, Horatio. Farewell, wretched queen! (informal: I'm gone, Horatio. Bye, wretched queen!)

dialogue: You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
paraphrased: You who seem pale and tremble at this opportunity,

dialogue: That are but mutes or audience to this act,
paraphrased: Those who are merely spectators or listeners to this event.

dialogue: Had I but time--as this fell sergeant, death,
paraphrased: If only I had the time, like this persistent servant, death.

dialogue: Is strict in his arrest--O, I could tell you--
paraphrased:
He's very strict with enforcing laws, let me tell you... (Informal)

or

He strictly adheres to making arrests, trust me on that... (Formal)

dialogue: But let it be. Horatio, I am dead;
paraphrased: But let it be, Horatio. I'm gone now.

dialogue: Thou livest; report me and my cause aright
paraphrased: You're alive; tell the truth about me and my situation accurately.

dialogue: To the unsatisfied.
paraphrased: To those who aren't content.

dialogue: Never believe it:
paraphrased: Never take it for granted.

dialogue: I am more an antique Roman than a Dane:
paraphrased: I'm more of a classical Roman than a Danish person.

dialogue: Here's yet some liquor left.
paraphrased: Here's a bit of alcohol remaining.

dialogue: As thou'rt a man,
paraphrased: As you are a man

dialogue: Give me the cup: let go; by heaven, I'll have't.
paraphrased:
Give me the cup: let it go; by heavens, I will get it. (informal)

  Give me the cup: relinquish it; on my honor, I'll claim it. (formal)

dialogue: O good Horatio, what a wounded name,
paraphrased: Oh, dear Horatio, what a disgraced reputation!

dialogue: Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me!
paraphrased: Things left mysteriously, will remain beyond me!

dialogue: If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart
paraphrased: If you've ever cared for me deeply

dialogue: Absent thee from felicity awhile,
paraphrased: Without you, I'm momentarily deprived of happiness.

dialogue: And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain,
paraphrased: In this tough world, breathe with discomfort.

dialogue: To tell my story.
paraphrased: To share my tale/experience.

dialogue: March afar off, and shot within
paraphrased: Move far away, then fire a shot at it (informal: aim and shoot)

dialogue: What warlike noise is this?
paraphrased: What's that aggressive sound?

dialogue: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland,
paraphrased:
Young Fortinbras, arriving from Poland after conquering,

or more concisely:

Young Fortinbras, freshly victorious in Poland, arrives.

dialogue: To the ambassadors of England gives
paraphrased: To the representatives of England, I give

dialogue: This warlike volley.
paraphrased: This aggressive barrage.

dialogue: O, I die, Horatio;
paraphrased: Oh, Horatio, I'm dying.

dialogue: The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit:
paraphrased: The powerful toxin overwhelms my spirit too much:

dialogue: I cannot live to hear the news from England;
paraphrased: I can't bear to learn the news from England.

dialogue: But I do prophesy the election lights
paraphrased: However, I predict the outcome of the election will be revealed.

dialogue: On Fortinbras: he has my dying voice;
paraphrased: On Fortinbras, I entrust my final words.

dialogue: So tell him, with the occurrents, more and less,
paraphrased: Inform him about the events, both many and few.

dialogue: Which have solicited. The rest is silence.
paraphrased: Those who asked for it remain unheard from since then.

dialogue: Dies
paraphrased: This dies.

dialogue: Now cracks a noble heart. Good night sweet prince:
paraphrased: Now, a valiant spirit breaks apart. Farewell, dear prince; rest in peace.

dialogue: And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!
paraphrased: Angels' choirs are singing you a farewell song now.

dialogue: Why does the drum come hither?
paraphrased: Why is the drum being brought here?

dialogue: March within
paraphrased: Walk in protest or demonstration

dialogue: Enter FORTINBRAS, the English Ambassadors, and others
paraphrased: Here enters Fortinbras, along with the English Ambassadors, and other characters.

dialogue: Where is this sight?
paraphrased: Where is this location?

dialogue: What is it ye would see?
paraphrased: What do you want to see?

dialogue: If aught of woe or wonder, cease your search.
paraphrased: If you're looking for any trouble or mystery, stop your quest.

dialogue: This quarry cries on havoc. O proud death,
paraphrased: This stone pit unleashes chaos. Haughty demise, here you are.

dialogue: What feast is toward in thine eternal cell,
paraphrased: What celebration lies ahead within your eternal abode?

dialogue: That thou so many princes at a shot
paraphrased: You could take out that many princes with a single shot.

dialogue: So bloodily hast struck?
paraphrased: Did you just strike violently?

dialogue: The sight is dismal;
paraphrased: The view is grim.

dialogue: And our affairs from England come too late:
paraphrased: News and communications from England are arriving too slowly for us.

dialogue: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing,
paraphrased: Ears that should be providing us with hearing are senseless. (Modern idiomatic English: deaf ears)

dialogue: To tell him his commandment is fulfill'd,
paraphrased: To let him know that his task is completed

dialogue: That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead:
paraphrased: It's confirmed that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are no longer alive.

dialogue: Where should we have our thanks?
paraphrased: Where should we express our gratitude?

dialogue: Not from his mouth,
paraphrased: Not spoken by him

dialogue: Had it the ability of life to thank you:
paraphrased: If it could express gratitude, it would thank you.

dialogue: He never gave commandment for their death.
paraphrased: He did not order their execution.

dialogue: But since, so jump upon this bloody question,
paraphrased: However, let's dive right into this issue, shall we?

dialogue: You from the Polack wars, and you from England,
paraphrased: You're from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and you're from England.

dialogue: Are here arrived give order that these bodies
paraphrased: Have arrived and issued orders for these individuals/objects.

dialogue: High on a stage be placed to the view;
paraphrased: Positioned atop a stage for all to see.

dialogue: And let me speak to the yet unknowing world
paraphrased: And allow me to address those yet unaware of our world

dialogue: How these things came about: so shall you hear
paraphrased: Here's how they originated: this is what you'll learn.

dialogue: Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,
paraphrased: About cruel, violent, and abnormal behaviors

dialogue: Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters,
paraphrased: Of unintentional decisions and careless killings,

dialogue: Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause,
paraphrased: Deaths that were either intentionally caused or resulted from compulsion

dialogue: And, in this upshot, purposes mistook
paraphrased: And consequently, intentions were misunderstood.

dialogue: Fall'n on the inventors' reads: all this can I
paraphrased: All of this is attributable to the inventors.

dialogue: Truly deliver.
paraphrased: Truly execute/fulfill/carry out.

dialogue: Let us haste to hear it,
paraphrased: Let's hurry up and find out!

dialogue: And call the noblest to the audience.
paraphrased: And summon the most distinguished.

dialogue: For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune:
paraphrased: For me, sadly, I accept my luck.

dialogue: I have some rights of memory in this kingdom,
paraphrased: I possess certain memory privileges within this realm.

dialogue: Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me.
paraphrased: Which position now entices me to take it up.

dialogue: Of that I shall have also cause to speak,
paraphrased: About that, I'll also share more details.

dialogue: And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more;
paraphrased: And from that source, voice emanates with even more power.

dialogue: But let this same be presently perform'd,
paraphrased: But let it be performed right now

dialogue: Even while men's minds are wild; lest more mischance
paraphrased: Even when people's thoughts are chaotic; to prevent further misfortune.

dialogue: On plots and errors, happen.
paraphrased: Issues like mistakes and errors can occur on plots (or in cases).

dialogue: Let four captains
paraphrased: Let there be four leaders (or heads)

dialogue: Bear Hamlet, like a soldier, to the stage;
paraphrased: Carry Hamlet, as a performer, onto the stage.

dialogue: For he was likely, had he been put on,
paraphrased: If he'd been given the opportunity, he probably would have performed.

dialogue: To have proved most royally: and, for his passage,
paraphrased:
To have demonstrated exceptionally well: and, to facilitate movement,

or more concisely:

To have shown exceptional proof: and, to make travel easier,

dialogue: The soldiers' music and the rites of war
paraphrased:
The military tunes and battle rituals

or more casually,

The troops' tunes and war routines

dialogue: Speak loudly for him.
paraphrased: Speak clearly and loudly for him.

dialogue: Take up the bodies: such a sight as this
paraphrased: Retrieve the bodies; this is quite a spectacle.

dialogue: Becomes the field, but here shows much amiss.
paraphrased: Becomes a field, yet reveals many issues here.

dialogue: Go, bid the soldiers shoot.
paraphrased: Go, tell the soldiers to fire.

dialogue: A dead march. Exeunt, bearing off the dead bodies; after which a peal of ordnance is shot off
paraphrased: A solemn procession departs, carrying away the deceased. Following this, a cannon salute echoes.
